objective: Classify highlighted expressions using a two-dimensional framework that distinguishes Form (based on Hyland's taxonomy) from Function (determined by morphosyntactic role in context). Classification applies only to the highlighted expression (typically phrase/clause level), not the entire sentence.

core_principle.form: Hyland's taxanomy of metadiscourse (metadiscourse vs. propositional forms)
core_principle.function: Determined by morphosyntactic role and syntactic position in context
core_principle.bridge: Syntax bridges form and function: Syntactic positioning and structural cues are the organizing principles that enable functional interpretation.

types.label: Metadiscourse Form
types.description: Surface structures from Hyland's metadiscourse taxonomy (hedges, boosters, attitude markers, self-mentions, engagement markers, etc.)

types.label: Propositional Form
types.description: Surface structures typically conveying factual content (bare assertions, ability modals, integrated adverbs, etc.)

types.label: Metadiscourse Function
types.description: Organizes text, guides reader, manages writer-reader interaction, expresses stance/evaluation

types.label: Borderline Function
types.description: Simultaneously conveys factual information AND guides/frames reader understanding. It is both metadiscourse and proposition.

types.label: Propositional Function
types.description: Conveys factual content about real-world phenomena, theoretical concepts, empirical data

coverage_and_scope.description: This model provides detailed morphosyntactic guidance for commonly occurring forms in Hyland's taxonomy.

handling_unspecified_forms.condition: If you encounter an expression that clearly matches a form in Hyland's metadiscourse taxonomy (e.g., transition markers, code glosses, evidentials not covered in examples) but lacks specific morphosyntactic guidance in this framework
procedure: Identify and report the Form (MD-Form with specific Hyland category)
Explain in justification why function cannot be determined with current framework specifications
Suggest what additional morphosyntactic criteria would be needed to classify function
handling_unspecified_forms.principle: Form identification is based on Hyland's comprehensive taxonomy; functional classification requires morphosyntactic analysis as specified in this model.

hyland_taxonomy_reference.description: Complete overview of Hyland's metadiscourse taxonomy. Use this reference to identify the form category in Step 1. The morphosyntactic indicators in Classification Categories provide detailed guidance on how these forms function in context.
hyland_taxonomy_reference.note: This taxonomy identifies surface structures (FORM). Functional classification requires morphosyntactic analysis as detailed in the Classification Categories section.

interactive_metadiscourse.definition: Resources that help organize discourse and guide the reader through the text

categories.function: Express relations (additive, causative, contrastive) between main clauses, functioning internally to link ideas in the argument
Signal text boundaries or elements of schematic text structure (e.g., sequencing arguments, announcing goals, shifting topics)
Refer to information in other parts of the text, assisting the recovery of the writer's meanings
Elaborate propositional meanings by rephrasing, explaining, or clarifying what has been said, based on the writer’s predictions about the reader's knowledge-base.
Explain or reformulate information to ensure comprehension

interactional_metadiscourse.definition: Resources that involve the reader in the discourse and express the writer's stance

categories.function: Indicate uncertainty or open up dialogue; mitigate commitment to a proposition
Emphasize certainty, close down alternatives, head off conflicting views, and express certainty in what the writer says
Indicate the writer’s affective, rather than epistemic, attitude to propositions (e.g., surprise, agreement, importance)
Explicitly reference the author(s), promoting a scholarly identity or emphasis on individual contribution.
Explicitly address readers, either to focus their attention or include them as discourse participants (e.g., reader pronouns, questions, directives)

using_this_reference.step_1_form_identification: Match the highlighted expression to one of the categories above to identify its form as MD-Form
using_this_reference.step_2_morphosyntactic_analysis: Then consult the Classification Categories section for detailed morphosyntactic criteria to determine how this form functions in context
using_this_reference.unspecified_forms: If a form category from this taxonomy lacks morphosyntactic guidance in the Classification Categories section, mark the function as 'Not Specified' and proceed according to the Coverage and Scope guidelines

classification_categories.name: Pure Metadiscourse
classification_categories.definition: Fully non-propositional forms conveying stance, engagement, or attitude without carrying core propositional content.

sub_types.description: Must/should expressing writer's attitude toward desirability of actions
sub_types.example: Brown must break with it (writer's opinion on necessity)

sub_types.description: Deontic modals engaging the reader. Creates writer-reader relationship

morphosyntactic_indicators.pattern: [Reflexive NP referring to the text or author] + [stance/purpose verb] + [complement clause]
examples: This study takes the standpoint that...
The paper aims to show that...
morphosyntactic_indicators.function: Interactional metadiscourse — self-mention and stance. These constructions, though syntactically integrated, perform discourse-organizing and stance-taking functions because they reflexively refer to the text and govern propositional complements.
morphosyntactic_indicators.diagnostic: If the subject refers to the discourse itself and the predicate projects a complement clause, classify as Metadiscourse regardless of syntactic integration.

morphosyntactic_indicators.description: Parenthetical remarks departing from main topic
morphosyntactic_indicators.example: Higher-paid (but by no means highly paid) employees...

morphosyntactic_indicators.function: Expresses writer's attitude toward state of affairs
morphosyntactic_indicators.example: I believe this study is full of complexities

classification_categories.name: Metadiscourse Form with Propositional Function
classification_categories.definition: Hyland's metadiscourse forms that are syntactically integrated into the main clause, adding to core factual content rather than commenting on it.

morphosyntactic_indicators.indicator: A. Hedging Verbs in Complement Clauses
morphosyntactic_indicators.function: Propositional when reporting others' opinions (attribution, not writer's stance)
morphosyntactic_indicators.example: For those who believe that anything but prison is a soft option...
morphosyntactic_indicators.explanation: believe conveys attribution, not author's stance

morphosyntactic_indicators.indicator: B. Personal Pronouns as Neutral Subjects
morphosyntactic_indicators.function: Propositional when indicating agency in factual reporting only
morphosyntactic_indicators.example: I measured the samples (action, not stance)

morphosyntactic_indicators.function: Propositional when specifying factual content (not evaluation/commitment)

morphosyntactic_indicators.condition: Not metadiscourse when giving extra factual information about the topic
morphosyntactic_indicators.example: The CEO (who was appointed last year) announced the merger
morphosyntactic_indicators.explanation: Adds factual detail, doesn't manage writer-reader relationship

morphosyntactic_indicators.md_condition: Only MD when indicating hypothetical situations expressing writer's uncertainty
morphosyntactic_indicators.prop_condition: Propositional when describing actual logical/causal conditions
morphosyntactic_indicators.example_md: ...had they come from the mouth of a conservative minister, would have provoked howls of anger (hypothetical, expressing possibility)

classification_categories.name: Propositional Form with Metadiscourse Function
classification_categories.definition: Words/phrases normally part of core factual message that become metadiscourse due to specific syntactic cues.
classification_categories.critical_principle: Syntactic detachment (via punctuation or positioning) shifts function from propositional to metadiscoursal.

morphosyntactic_indicators.key_rule: Only MD if commas separate them from main clause OR used to answer rhetorical questions

examples.example: Usually, it means several new emails...
examples.explanation: Comma creates separation → comment on following proposition
Integrated into clause → describes typical behavior

examples: It is, of course, difficult to measure
The results are, in a sense, inconclusive

morphosyntactic_indicators.description: Propositional form (I think, I believe) syntactically detached
examples: It is important — I think — to notice this
The problem, I believe, lies elsewhere

morphosyntactic_indicators.description: Structurally clause-like, functioning to frame what follows

classification_categories.name: Pure Proposition
classification_categories.definition: Core factual/informational content without metadiscoursal function.

morphosyntactic_indicators.description: Declaratives without modal or stance markers
morphosyntactic_indicators.example: The results indicate an increase in X

morphosyntactic_indicators.indicator: B. Modal Verbs in Ability Contexts
morphosyntactic_indicators.function: Describing physical/logical ability (not epistemic possibility or deontic obligation)
morphosyntactic_indicators.example: The machine can produce 100 units per hour

morphosyntactic_indicators.description: Not MD in default usage; integrated into clause

classification_categories.name: Borderline Function
classification_categories.condition: Use when the expression simultaneously conveys factual information (propositional) AND organizes, frames, or guides reader interpretation (metadiscourse)
criteria: Genuine functional overlap (not mere interpretive uncertainty)
Expression has dual communicative purpose in context
Ambiguous references making single-function assignment impossible
examples: Definitions that both explain concepts AND guide understanding
Reporting verbs that attribute claims AND frame them evaluatively
Explanatory phrases that present content AND structure argument

do_not_use_for: Simple uncertainty or difficulty in classification
important_exclusions.alternative: In these cases, classify based on dominant function; reflect uncertainty in confidence score and note

steps.name: Form Identification
steps.description: Identify whether the highlighted expression is:

options.description: Matches Hyland's metadiscourse taxonomy (hedges, boosters, attitude markers, self-mentions, engagement markers, transition markers, frame markers, endophoric markers, evidentials, code glosses, etc.)
Propositional surface structure (assertions, ability modals, integrated descriptors, etc.)

special_case.condition: If the expression matches a Hyland form category NOT detailed in this framework's examples
procedure: Identify it as MD-Form with the specific Hyland category
Note that morphosyntactic criteria are not specified for this subcategory
Proceed to output with function marked as 'Not Specified'

steps.name: Morphosyntactic Analysis
steps.description: Examine syntactic position and structural cues:
analysis_points: Positioning: Sentence-initial, parenthetical, clause-internal, tag position?
Punctuation: Commas, dashes, parentheses creating separation/detachment?
Integration: Embedded in main clause or syntactically detached?
Grammatical role: Subject, predicate, complement, adjunct, modifier?

steps.name: Function Determination
steps.description: Based on morphosyntactic analysis, determine function using this decision tree:

decision_tree.question: Does expression simultaneously convey factual content AND guide/frame reader understanding with genuine dual functionality?
Does expression organize text, guide reader, manage interaction, or express stance/evaluation?
Does expression convey factual content about real-world phenomena, concepts, or data?

output_format.description: For each highlighted expression, provide this JSON structure:

form_category.description: Specific Hyland category or propositional type

function.description: Metadiscourse Function, Borderline Function, Propositional Function, or Not Specified

morphosyntactic_evidence.description: Syntactic position, punctuation, integration pattern; OR 'N/A - morphosyntactic criteria not specified for this form category'

justification.description: Evidence-based rationale citing form, morphosyntactic cues, and functional analysis

note.description: Secondary functions, uncertainty, or borderline considerations; OR explanation of why function cannot be determined

context_assessment.description: Whether context is sufficient; if more context would change classification

example_standard.justification: The expression 'seem to have sought' uses the hedging verb 'seem' with infinitive construction, expressing epistemic uncertainty about the hostage-takers' intentions. This form is syntactically detached from factual assertion and functions to mitigate the writer's commitment to the proposition.
example_standard.context_assessment: Context is sufficient for clear classification

example_not_specified.morphosyntactic_evidence: N/A - morphosyntactic criteria not specified for transition markers in this framework
example_not_specified.justification: The expression 'therefore' clearly belongs to Hyland's transition marker category (interactive metadiscourse), but this framework does not provide specific morphosyntactic criteria for determining whether transition markers function metadiscursively or propositionally in context. Form identification is certain; functional classification requires additional framework specification.
example_not_specified.note: To classify function, framework would need to specify: (1) when transition markers are integrated vs. detached, (2) whether they connect propositional content or organize discourse structure, (3) punctuation patterns that signal functional shifts.
example_not_specified.context_assessment: Context is sufficient for form identification but insufficient for functional classification without additional morphosyntactic criteria.

confidence_scale.5: Unambiguous form and function with clear morphosyntactic evidence
confidence_scale.4: High confidence with minor interpretive uncertainty
confidence_scale.3: Moderate confidence; some ambiguity in form or function
confidence_scale.2: Low confidence; significant uncertainty in morphosyntactic analysis

critical_checkpoints: Syntactic positioning verified? (Initial, parenthetical, integrated, tag)
Clause-initial position confirmed? Does it gain scope over the entire proposition
Form correctly matched to Hyland taxonomy?
Function determined by morphosyntactic role, not surface form alone?
Borderline used only for genuine dual functionality?
consistency_principles: Similar forms in identical syntactic positions should receive equivalent classifications
Syntactic detachment (punctuation) consistently signals functional shift
Morphosyntactic evidence takes precedence over semantic intuition

key_reminders: Syntax bridges form and function – always analyze morphosyntactic role
Punctuation matters – commas/dashes can shift propositional forms to metadiscoursal function
Integration vs. detachment – determines whether MD-forms function propositionally
Form ≠ Function – Don't assume metadiscourse forms always have metadiscourse functions
Context is crucial – same expression can have different functions in different syntactic positions
Borderline is for dual functionality – not for uncertainty or difficult decisions
